title: Deuteronomy Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 28.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28:1, what will happen if you diligently obey the voice of the LORD your God?
options: The LORD will set you on high above all nations of the earth
You will be hidden from your enemies
You will become poor and oppressed
You will be forgotten by all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will set you on high above all nations of the earth
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:1 promises that if you obey God's commandments, the LORD will set you on high above all nations of the earth.

questions.question: What blessing is mentioned in Deuteronomy 28:3?
options: Blessed shalt thou be in the city and in the field
Blessed shalt thou be with many children
Blessed shalt thou be with wealth and gold
Blessed shalt thou be with peace and quiet
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed shalt thou be in the city and in the field
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:3 specifically states that you will be blessed in the city and in the field.

questions.question: What will happen to your enemies according to Deuteronomy 28:7?
options: They shall be smitten before your face and flee seven ways
They shall join you in peace
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be smitten before your face and flee seven ways
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:7 says the LORD will cause your enemies to be smitten before you and flee in seven ways.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28:12, what will the LORD open unto you?
options: His good treasure, the heaven to give rain
questions.correctAnswer: His good treasure, the heaven to give rain
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:12 states the LORD will open His good treasure, the heaven, to give rain in its season to bless your work.

questions.question: What will you become if you hearken unto the commandments of the LORD according to Deuteronomy 28:13?
options: The head and not the tail
questions.correctAnswer: The head and not the tail
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:13 promises that if you obey God's commandments, you shall be the head and not the tail.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 28:16 states that you will be blessed in the city and in the field.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:16 says you will be cursed in the city and in the field if you do not obey, not blessed.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28:22, which of the following is NOT listed as a plague the LORD will smite you with?
questions.correctAnswer: Flood
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:22 lists consumption, fever, inflammation, extreme burning, sword, blasting, mildew but not flood.

questions.question: What will happen to your ox and your ass according to Deuteronomy 28:31?
options: Thine ox shall be slain before thine eyes, and thine ass shall be taken away
They shall be given as gifts to neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: Thine ox shall be slain before thine eyes, and thine ass shall be taken away
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:31 explains that your ox will be killed before you and your ass taken violently away.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Deuteronomy 28:6: 'Blessed shalt thou be when thou ______, and blessed shalt thou be when thou goest out.'
questions.correctAnswer: comest in
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:6 states you will be blessed when you come in and when you go out.

questions.question: Who shall you serve if you do not obey the LORD according to Deuteronomy 28:48?
options: Thine enemies which the LORD shall send against thee
questions.correctAnswer: Thine enemies which the LORD shall send against thee
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:48 says you shall serve your enemies whom the LORD sends against you if you disobey.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 28:37, you shall become an astonishment, a proverb, and a byword among all nations.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:37 states that you will be an astonishment, proverb, and byword among all nations.

questions.question: What will happen to your vineyard according to Deuteronomy 28:39?
options: You shall neither drink of the wine nor gather the grapes
It shall be protected by angels
It shall be destroyed by fire
questions.correctAnswer: You shall neither drink of the wine nor gather the grapes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:39 says you will plant and dress vineyards but neither drink nor gather the grapes because worms will eat them.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28:49, from where will the LORD bring a nation against you?
options: From far, from the end of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: From far, from the end of the earth
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:49 states the LORD will bring a nation from far, from the end of the earth, as swift as an eagle.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 28:10 says all people of the earth shall be afraid of you because you are called by the name of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:10 explains that all people will see you are called by the LORD's name and will fear you.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28:53, what desperate act will people do during the siege and distress?
options: Eat the flesh of their own sons and daughters
questions.correctAnswer: Eat the flesh of their own sons and daughters
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:53 describes that people will eat the flesh of their own children during extreme distress.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Deuteronomy 28:12: '...and bless all the work of thine hand: and thou shalt ______ unto many nations, and thou shalt not borrow.'
questions.correctAnswer: lend
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:12 says you shall lend unto many nations and not borrow if blessed.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commands. Based on Deuteronomy 28, what blessing can you encourage them to expect if they diligently obey?
options: They will be set high above all nations
They will be ignored by others
questions.correctAnswer: They will be set high above all nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:1 teaches that if one hearkens diligently to God's voice and obeys His commandments, the LORD will set them on high above all nations. This is supported by verses 2, 8, and 13 which speak of blessings and being made the head, not the tail.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 28 teach about God's provision for those who obey Him in their daily work and stewardship?
options: God will bless all the work of their hands
God will take away their possessions
They will need to borrow often
questions.correctAnswer: God will bless all the work of their hands
questions.explanation: Verse 12 promises that the LORD will bless the work of the obedient person's hands and open good treasures of heaven to give rain in its season. Verses 5 and 8 also mention blessings on the basket, store, and all they set their hand to.

questions.question: A believer is facing opposition and enemies. According to Deuteronomy 28, what assurance can you share about God's protection?
options: The LORD will cause enemies to flee before them in seven ways
They must rely on their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will cause enemies to flee before them in seven ways
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:7 says the LORD shall cause enemies that rise against you to be smitten and flee before you seven ways. Verse 25 contrasts this by warning of defeat if disobedient.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 teach about the relationship between obedience and family blessings?
options: Obedience leads to blessing of children and increase
Family blessings are unrelated to obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to blessing of children and increase
questions.explanation: Verse 4 speaks of blessing the fruit of the body, ground, cattle, increase of kine and flocks as a result of obedience. Verse 11 also mentions plenteous goods and fruit of the body in the promised land.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by hardships and wonders if God is punishing them. According to Deuteronomy 28, what is the biblical reason for such difficulties?
options: Disobedience and forsaking God bring curses and destruction
Hardships come only from the world
Difficulties are always a test of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience and forsaking God bring curses and destruction
questions.explanation: Verse 15 clearly states that if one does not obey the LORD, curses will come upon them. Verses 20-22 list various calamities due to wickedness and forsaking God. This aligns with verses 45 and 63 about punishment for disobedience.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 28 instruct believers about humility and contentment in possessions?
options: Blessings come when one obediently trusts God, not by striving alone
Possessions are guaranteed regardless of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Blessings come when one obediently trusts God, not by striving alone
questions.explanation: Verses 1-14 emphasize blessings linked to obedience and God's favor rather than human effort alone. Trusting and hearkening to the LORD leads to abundance, while failure to obey leads to loss (verses 38-40). This instructs humility and reliance on God.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 28 teaches that if a believer does not obey God, they will be given rest and peace among nations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 65 states that among the nations where God scatters disobedient people, they will find no ease or rest, but trembling hearts and sorrow. This indicates unrest and fear, not peace.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 28, obedience to God results in being the 'head and not the tail'.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 13 explicitly states that if the commandments are obeyed, the LORD will make the obedient person the head and not the tail, above only and not beneath.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 28 teaches that if you do not serve the LORD with joyfulness and gladness of heart, you will __________.
options: serve your enemies in hunger and thirst
receive good gifts from the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: serve your enemies in hunger and thirst
questions.explanation: Verse 47-48 explain that failure to serve the LORD with joy results in serving enemies in hunger, thirst, nakedness, and want, with a yoke of iron upon the neck until destruction.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their work seems to yield little fruit. How does Deuteronomy 28 explain this experience if it is due to disobedience?
options: Locusts consume the seed and worms eat the grapes
God rewards all hard work equally
questions.correctAnswer: Locusts consume the seed and worms eat the grapes
questions.explanation: Verses 38-39 describe how the disobedient will sow much seed but gather little because locusts consume it, and they will plant vineyards but not drink wine because worms eat the grapes.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28, what happens to a believer’s family if they disobey God?
options: Their sons and daughters will be given to another people
Their family will be blessed and protected
questions.correctAnswer: Their sons and daughters will be given to another people
questions.explanation: Verse 32 warns that disobedient people will have their sons and daughters given to another nation, and they will long for them all day without power to help.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 28 teach about the importance of faithfulness in marriage and family life?
options: Disobedience results in a wife being taken by another man
Marriage is guaranteed to be peaceful regardless
Family life is not connected to obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience results in a wife being taken by another man
questions.explanation: Verse 30 describes that if the people disobey, they may betroth a wife but another man will lie with her, and build a house but not dwell in it, illustrating broken family blessings.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 teach about the consequences of turning to serve other gods?
options: You will be scattered among nations and serve gods of wood and stone
You will find peace and rest
questions.correctAnswer: You will be scattered among nations and serve gods of wood and stone
questions.explanation: Verses 36 and 64 explain that disobedient people and their leaders will be brought to a foreign nation to serve other gods made of wood and stone, and will be scattered among all peoples.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28, what attitude should believers maintain toward God's commandments to experience blessing?
questions.correctAnswer: Joyfulness and gladness of heart
questions.explanation: Verse 47 states that serving the LORD with joyfulness and gladness is key; failure to do so results in curses and hardship as described in subsequent verses.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear and anxiety. Based on Deuteronomy 28, what biblical truth would you share about God's discipline and restoration?
options: God may bring fear to discipline but desires to bless and multiply
Fear is always a sign of rejection by God
Anxiety proves lack of faith only
God ignores the suffering of His people
questions.correctAnswer: God may bring fear to discipline but desires to bless and multiply
questions.explanation: Verses 63-66 explain that as God rejoiced to do good and multiply, He may also bring destruction for disobedience, causing fear and doubt. The overall context shows His desire for obedience and blessing.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 say about lending and borrowing in the life of one who obeys God's commandments?
options: They shall lend to many nations but not borrow
They will constantly borrow and fail to lend
Lending and borrowing are unrelated to obedience
They will be heavily in debt
questions.correctAnswer: They shall lend to many nations but not borrow
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that the LORD will bless the obedient so that they shall lend to many nations and not borrow, showing God's provision and economic blessing tied to obedience.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 28.

questions.question: What is the primary condition for Israel to be set 'on high above all nations' according to Deuteronomy 28?
options: Hearkening diligently unto the voice of the LORD and doing all His commandments
Building a temple in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Hearkening diligently unto the voice of the LORD and doing all His commandments
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:1 states that if Israel hearkens diligently unto the voice of the LORD and observes all His commandments, then the LORD will set them on high above all nations.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 28, what literary device is prominently used by contrasting blessings and curses?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The chapter is structured with blessings described first, then a parallel section of curses, forming a chiastic pattern emphasizing covenant obedience and its consequences (28:1-14 blessings; 28:15-68 curses).

questions.question: Which imagery in Deuteronomy 28:7 symbolizes overwhelming victory over enemies?
options: Enemies coming one way and fleeing seven ways
questions.correctAnswer: Enemies coming one way and fleeing seven ways
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says the LORD will cause enemies to come against Israel one way and flee seven ways, symbolizing total and overwhelming defeat.

questions.question: What type of 'head' and 'tail' imagery is used in Deuteronomy 28 to depict Israel's status among nations?
options: Being the head (leader) and not the tail (follower)
Being the tail (follower) and not the head (leader)
Both head and tail being cut off
Neither head nor tail but the body
questions.correctAnswer: Being the head (leader) and not the tail (follower)
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:13 uses the metaphor of Israel being the head and not the tail, indicating leadership and prominence if they obey God.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 28:12 mentions the LORD opening 'his good treasure, the heaven to give the rain unto thy land in his season.' What is the significance of this in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Rain was vital for agriculture and a sign of divine blessing
Rain was unrelated to divine favor
questions.correctAnswer: Rain was vital for agriculture and a sign of divine blessing
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, rain was crucial for crops, so God providing rain symbolized His blessing and favor, as stated in Deuteronomy 28:12.

questions.question: Which New Testament book alludes to the blessings and curses covenant theme found in Deuteronomy 28?
questions.correctAnswer: Galatians
questions.explanation: Galatians 3 discusses the covenant blessings and curses in relation to the law and faith, reflecting on Deuteronomy 28’s covenant structure.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'blessed shalt thou be when thou comest in, and blessed shalt thou be when thou goest out' (Deut. 28:6) in terms of Israelite daily life and societal movement?
options: It signifies God's protection and blessing in all daily activities and travels
It refers only to entering and leaving the temple
It means blessings only at harvest time
It is a metaphor for spiritual blessings only
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies God's protection and blessing in all daily activities and travels
questions.explanation: The verse blesses both coming in and going out, indicating comprehensive divine protection in all aspects of life and movement.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 28:15, the curses come upon Israel if they serve other gods instead of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:15 warns that if Israel does not obey God's commandments and serves other gods, curses will come upon them.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 28:22, multiple afflictions are listed as curses. Which of the following is NOT mentioned among them?
questions.correctAnswer: Blindness
questions.explanation: Blindness is mentioned later in verse 28, not in verse 22. Verse 22 lists consumption, fever, inflammation, burning, sword, blasting, and mildew.

questions.question: What does the 'locust' symbolize in the curses of Deuteronomy 28:38 and 42 in terms of agricultural disaster?
options: A devouring plague that destroys crops
questions.correctAnswer: A devouring plague that destroys crops
questions.explanation: Locusts are portrayed as destructive pests consuming crops, symbolizing famine and divine judgment in Deuteronomy 28:38 and 42.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28:36, what fate is foretold for Israel's king if they disobey God?
options: Being brought to a foreign nation to serve other gods
Becoming a great ruler over many nations
questions.correctAnswer: Being brought to a foreign nation to serve other gods
questions.explanation: Verse 36 foretells that the king and the people will be taken to a foreign nation where they will serve other gods of wood and stone due to disobedience.

questions.question: How does the theme of 'servitude and exile' in Deuteronomy 28:64-68 resonate with Israel's historical experience in the Babylonian exile?
options: It foreshadows Israel's scattering and servitude among nations
It predicts an eternal possession of the land
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Israel's scattering and servitude among nations
questions.explanation: Verses 64-68 describe scattering among nations and servitude, foreshadowing the Babylonian exile and subsequent diaspora.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word theme expressing 'hearkening' or 'listening' is the basis for receiving blessings in Deuteronomy 28:1-2?
questions.correctAnswer: Shema (to hear, listen, obey)
questions.explanation: The command to 'hearken' (shema) underlines obedience as the condition for blessings, aligning with the central covenant concept of listening to God.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'sign and wonder' mentioned in Deuteronomy 28:46 regarding the curses?
options: To serve as a perpetual reminder of covenant faithfulness or failure
To indicate the end of days
questions.correctAnswer: To serve as a perpetual reminder of covenant faithfulness or failure
questions.explanation: Verse 46 states the curses will be a sign and a wonder upon Israel and their seed forever, emphasizing covenant consequences.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 28 describes both material and social consequences for Israel's disobedience.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter details curses affecting crops, health, social relations, captivity, and exile, indicating comprehensive consequences for disobedience.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28, what conditions must Israel fulfill to receive God's blessings?
options: Hearken diligently to the voice of the LORD and observe all His commandments
Build a temple in every city
questions.correctAnswer: Hearken diligently to the voice of the LORD and observe all His commandments
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:1 clearly states that blessings come if Israel hearkens diligently to the voice of the LORD and observes all His commandments. This principle is consistent with scriptures such as Exodus 19:5, Leviticus 26:3, John 14:15, and 1 John 5:3, where obedience to God’s commands results in blessing and favor.

questions.question: What is one of the blessings promised to Israel in Deuteronomy 28 for obedience?
options: The LORD will set thee on high above all nations of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will set thee on high above all nations of the earth
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:1 promises that God will exalt Israel above all nations if they obey Him. This theme of God’s exaltation of His people is echoed in Psalms 147:20, Isaiah 60:3, Matthew 5:14, and Romans 8:17, where God’s people are called to be a light and exalted for His glory.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a blessing listed in Deuteronomy 28 for obedience?
options: Blessed shall be thy basket and thy store
Blessed shalt thou be in the city and in the field
Thou shalt never face any enemies
The LORD shall command the blessing upon thee in all thy works
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt never face any enemies
questions.explanation: While Deuteronomy 28:7 speaks of the LORD causing enemies to flee, it does not promise the absence of enemies. Rather, blessings include prosperity, protection, and success in work (verses 3-8). Biblical consistency is found in Psalms 34:7, Romans 8:35, and Ephesians 6:12, where believers face enemies but are protected by God.

questions.question: What is the consequence if Israel does NOT obey the LORD according to Deuteronomy 28?
options: All these curses shall come upon thee and overtake thee
God will ignore them but still bless them
They will be immediately forgiven without consequences
They will be transported to another land without punishment
questions.correctAnswer: All these curses shall come upon thee and overtake thee
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:15 teaches that disobedience will result in curses overtaking the people. This is consistent with the biblical principle of sowing and reaping (Galatians 6:7), divine discipline (Hebrews 12:6), and the warnings in Leviticus 26:14-39 and Jeremiah 11:3-5.

questions.question: Which of the following curses is specifically mentioned in Deuteronomy 28 as a result of disobedience?
options: Smiting with madness, blindness, and astonishment of heart
questions.correctAnswer: Smiting with madness, blindness, and astonishment of heart
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:28 describes God smiting the disobedient with madness, blindness, and astonishment of heart. This reflects the spiritual and physical consequences of sin, similar to 2 Chronicles 36:16, Isaiah 59:10, John 9:39-41, and Romans 1:21-28.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 28 states, 'The LORD shall make thee the head, and not the ____.'
questions.correctAnswer: tail
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:13 emphasizes God's promise that Israel will be the head and not the tail, symbolizing leadership and prominence. This is echoed in Isaiah 9:6-7, Daniel 2:44, and Matthew 28:18 where God's kingdom and people are exalted above all.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 say about Israel's enemies if they obey God?
options: Enemies will be smitten before them and flee seven ways
questions.correctAnswer: Enemies will be smitten before them and flee seven ways
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:7 promises that the LORD will cause enemies to be smitten and flee before Israel in multiple directions. This reflects God's protection and victory granted to His people as affirmed in Exodus 14:14, Psalm 18:39, Romans 8:31, and Revelation 17:14.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28, what will happen to Israel’s fruit and labor if they disobey?
options: A nation which thou knowest not shall eat it up
It will be given as offerings
questions.correctAnswer: A nation which thou knowest not shall eat it up
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:33 explains that disobedience results in strangers consuming Israel's fruit and labor, symbolizing loss and devastation. This aligns with Jeremiah 5:17, Ezekiel 36:5, Hosea 8:8, and Matthew 21:33-41 where foreign nations or enemies consume what God’s people had.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 teach about the relationship between obedience and God's establishment of Israel as a holy people?
options: The LORD shall establish thee an holy people unto himself if thou keep His commandments
Israel is holy by birthright regardless of obedience
Holiness is unrelated to covenant obedience
Only the priests are holy, not the nation
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shall establish thee an holy people unto himself if thou keep His commandments
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:9 links holiness to covenant obedience. This theme is consistent with Leviticus 20:26, 1 Peter 2:9, Hebrews 12:14, and Romans 12:1-2, where God's people are called to be holy by following His ways.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the eschatological warning in Deuteronomy 28 about captivity?
options: Thy sons and daughters shall be given unto another people
Israel will never be taken captive
Captivity only affects the land, not the people
Captivity will last only one generation
questions.correctAnswer: Thy sons and daughters shall be given unto another people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:32 predicts the exile of Israel’s children to foreign peoples as judgment for disobedience. This is consistent with 2 Kings 17:6, Jeremiah 29:10, Ezekiel 12:15, and Luke 21:24, which describe exile and dispersion as a consequence of covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 say about the rain and harvest if Israel disobeys God?
options: The LORD shall make the rain of thy land powder and dust
The rain will fall in abundance
Harvest will be plentiful without labor
Rain will fall only at night
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shall make the rain of thy land powder and dust
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:24 states that the rain will become dust, symbolizing drought and failed harvests as a curse. This motif is seen in 1 Kings 8:35, Jeremiah 14:1-6, Amos 4:7, and Revelation 8:7, where divine judgment brings drought and famine.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28, what is the fate of Israel’s livestock in the event of disobedience?
options: Thine ox shall be slain before thine eyes, and thou shalt not eat thereof
They will be sacred and untouchable
They will all flee to the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Thine ox shall be slain before thine eyes, and thou shalt not eat thereof
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:31 describes the death and loss of livestock as part of the curses for disobedience. This reflects the comprehensive nature of divine judgment affecting possessions as seen in Exodus 9:3, 1 Samuel 5:6-12, Zechariah 11:4-6, and Revelation 6:8.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 say about Israel’s status among nations if they disobey?
options: Thou shalt become an astonishment, a proverb, and a byword among all nations
Thou shalt be exalted above all nations
Thou shalt be ignored and forgotten
Thou shalt be immediately destroyed without trace
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt become an astonishment, a proverb, and a byword among all nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:37 says disobedient Israel will be a byword among the nations, meaning a warning example. This is consistent with Ezekiel 36:20, Lamentations 1:12, Matthew 5:13, and Acts 13:47, where Israel's suffering serves as a sign to other nations.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 28, what is the significance of fearing the name of the LORD in relation to obedience?
options: Observing the law leads to fearing the glorious and fearful name of the LORD
Fearing the LORD's name is unrelated to obedience
Fearing the LORD's name means avoiding all human contact
Fearing the LORD's name guarantees exemption from all curses
questions.correctAnswer: Observing the law leads to fearing the glorious and fearful name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:58 connects obedience with reverence for the LORD's name, emphasizing covenant faithfulness. This aligns with Proverbs 9:10, Psalm 111:9, Isaiah 8:13, and Philippians 2:10, where the fear of God is foundational to holiness and relationship with Him.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 28 say about the diseases that will come upon Israel if they disobey?
options: The LORD will bring all the diseases of Egypt and others not written in the law
Diseases will only affect the animals
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will bring all the diseases of Egypt and others not written in the law
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:60-61 warns that disobedience will bring plagues including the feared diseases of Egypt and others not mentioned in the law. This reflects God's sovereign judgment as seen in Exodus 15:26, Numbers 12:9-10, Psalm 91:3, and Revelation 16:2.

questions.question: What promise does Deuteronomy 28 make regarding Israel’s lending and borrowing if they obey God?
options: Thou shalt lend unto many nations, and shalt not borrow
Thou shalt borrow from many nations
Thou shalt neither lend nor borrow
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt lend unto many nations, and shalt not borrow
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28:12 promises financial prosperity including lending to many nations without need to borrow if Israel obeys God. This principle of divine provision is echoed in Psalms 112:5, Proverbs 22:7, Matthew 6:31-33, and 2 Corinthians 9:8.

questions.question: Which of the following summarizes the ultimate purpose of the blessings and curses in Deuteronomy 28?
options: To teach Israel to fear the LORD and keep His commandments
To promote national pride and independence from God
To guarantee earthly success regardless of moral conduct
To show that God’s laws are optional
questions.correctAnswer: To teach Israel to fear the LORD and keep His commandments
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28 frames blessings and curses as means to instill reverence and obedience toward God (verses 58-59). This aligns with Ecclesiastes 12:13, Deuteronomy 10:12-13, Psalm 25:14, and Romans 11:22, emphasizing holiness and covenant faithfulness as the foundation of life.
